text: Patient: I think that’s probably his standard of care that he has to follow up, but if you’re following up - Doctor: Well, I would keep the appointment with him in January. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, maybe after that I could see you in April and if it turns out in January, your PSA has, you know, gone - instead of continuing to go south, it’s gone north, or we may, we may need to switch treatments whatever, then I would, I would maybe see you sooner to discuss that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, I, why don’t I - I’m going to make the appointment, I think, part of this appointment this January and, uh, I’m not sure if he’s doing the six-month injection, but, um, I’ll make an appointment for, it’s says April sixteenth. I’ll just make it April seventeenth which is a Tuesday. And, you don’t have to see him; you just see me. Family Member: Not the sixteenth? Doctor: I’ll e-mail him, but you can also tell him at the next appointment. Patient: I will. Doctor: You think it’s best – does he think it’s a good idea? He and I do this all the time. We, we transition after he’s finished with the radiation part. Because, unless - I mean, he’s not going away. We might need him again. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Down the road maybe. I don’t know. I hope not. But, but, but I think in terms of talking about the next trials, all those kinds of things, you need to be with, you’re going to, that’s going to be me. Okay?

text: Family Member: Ahhhh. Doctor: We can get a PSA. If that PSA is higher than what we have, then R_ will sort of talk to you about coming back down to get some of this other stuff. Doctor: If they think you make enough money that you should be able to pay for it, then they’re not gonna give you one of these, uh, uh, grants.

text: Patient: Every time I go in… Doctor: You just go and get your injection? Patient: Yeah and I think it would be better off do everything here. Doctor: Okay. Well I’m just wondering then if we should hold off and uh because we may have to switch him to Firmagon if he’s not getting enough suppression. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, okay. Doctor: Okay so why don’t you hold off on the injection tomorrow. Patient: Don’t take it tomorrow? Doctor: Don’t take it tomorrow. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me see what your testosterone level is and I’m going to put in for a different injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately that means it’ll have to be a monthly shot, but you know we may have to do that if your testosterone is not suppressed. Because if the Lupron is not working for you…

text: Patient: Hey! I want to know. Doctor: Okay. So, there’s a gene called BRCA2 which is – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Associated with prostate and breast cancer. I’ll write it down for you. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Um, that your – you have a mutation that you’ve inherited. What does that mean? Um. Well, we know that BRCA2 can be, um, a predisposition to getting prostate cancer. Patient: Well, I should tell you that -- I think it happened since I saw you – my brother was diagnosed. Doctor: With prostate cancer also? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Yeah. You’re one – Patient: Now, his scans came back --- bone scan and CAT scan came back, uh, uh, what do you call it? Negative. Positive? Nothing wrong which – Doctor: Now, remind me again, your children? How many children do you have? Patient: He is five years older.

Patient: …and they said they’re starting to see some success. Doctor: Yes. Doctor: So we’re gonna tap into those. There’s also um this new trial that’s looking at PSMA that I’m quite interested in. Just a matter of if we have a slot or not. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: Uh, so we have one granddaughter, E_, and two grandsons. Um. My, my youngest daughter deals with a lot of, uh, medical issues. Um. Uh. Anything else? Doctor: So, my advice, my advice is that um they should all get tested. Because this is a gene that, you know, there’s a lot of genes that we’re doing mutation tests and a lot of them, we don’t even know how predisposing it is to cancer for you - let alone if somebody inherits it. But, this is the one that we know if you have this, it predisposes you to getting cancer. And, that’s why I said, it’s a genie out of the bottle, because some people just don’t wanna know. They don’t wanna know that they’re –- Family Member: Why? Their children! Wouldn’t they want to get tested? Doctor: No, the children don’t want to know? Family Member: They don’t? Doctor: Well. I’m leaving that to you – you’re going to have to have a discussion with them to say, you know. Patient: No, she’s, she’s asking why wouldn’t people want to know. Doctor: Some people don’t want to know. Because now it’s an anxiety you gotta live with, and you know, it doesn’t necessarily mean one-hundred percent, but if you have it, it’s a very high chance that, particularly for breast cancer, you could get breast cancer. So. Patient: My, my children? Doctor: Your children. Patient: And my grandchildren? Family Member: Yes.

text: Patient: Yes.Yes Doctor: Have you, had you heard that before? Patient: Not really. No. Doctor: When you were, when you got treated with the radiation, did they present any other options for treatment at that point or was it just you have to have radiation. Patient: Just have to have radiation. Doctor: Alright. Patient: It wasn't really great in detail. Doctor: Okay, so this is the, this is the consent form for the MAP trial. So this is the MAP trial phase three, meaning that it's just more advanced and we're comparing it against placebo and it's a large trial. So I want you to take this home, I want you to read it, and I want you to think about it. I'll contact our research nurses too to see if you're eligible. And then we'll give you a call tomorrow and you can tell me. Yes, I think this is reasonable. Let's keep going. You can tell me- Patient: Trust me, I don’t have to wait until next week. Family Member: Trust me, he'll sign it right now. Patient: I’m serious. Family Member: I mean, he's ready to go. We kind of talked about it. Okay. Doctor: You know, so what were the discussion or what were you thinking or what were the discussions that you were having before?

You know it helps the chemo work better. So that you’re going to go back on morning and evening, five milligrams. Family Member: Okay. HCP She can just leave it right there Doctor: So that is something I’ll need to send in. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then I’ll send in the Zofran or what do you want to do? text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And there’s actually a group that would get you back to California. There’s a group at UCLA (laughs) Patient: And how does, what’s the effect of that when you get treated? I mean what is, what’s different about that? Would that, would that go after the growth in the lymph nodes? Doctor: Yes. So PSMA is a thing that’s on the surface of crossing cancer cells. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it’s an enzyme, which means uh we’re not really sure what it does but we are, we’re able to block its function with a with a small drug. Uh and what people actually here when we started doing it, uh people thought well that would be cool to take an image of the cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which will see where it is. So we put a little radioactive tag- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and the only PSMA does is go from the surface inside the cancer cell, and it’s almost, it’s almost a way to build something up inside. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we can get a really nice picture. Well, the next easy lead from there is why not put something that’s a killer mode. Uh what they’ve seen, and what’s been published in the German, mostly Germany, it’s relatively nontoxic. Uh the big toxicity has been uh the salivary glands seem to make PSMA also. So some people end up with dry mouth uh as a side effect. Uh the kidney also makes P- PSMA. They haven’t really reported acute kidney damage, hasn’t really been a big issue, but they haven’t really followed the people long enough I think to know-

text: Patient: Is my lack of uninterrupted sleep. I just don’t get it. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I don’t get – there’s never a night that I get three or four hours uninterrupted sleep. Doctor: Cause you’re peeing? Patient: Um, yes. Doctor: Yeah. So what time do you stop drinking? Patient: Every time I get up, I drink some more water. (Laughter) Doctor: That’s why you keep peeing. Patient: But everybody told me to drink more water. Family Member: No. During the day. Doctor: During the day. You should shut your water drinking at seven o’clock. Doctor: Yes. And then you’ll stop peeing at night. And then you’ll wake up and drink all day until you stop at seven o’clock. Family Member: When they were doing the (Xofigo)

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
